['Circle - A round shape or area with all points at an equal distance from its center.', 'Circling - Moving in circular paths, often as part of a routine or process.', 'Circumscribed - To draw around (an object) forming a circle that contains it entirely.', 'Circumference - The total length of the outer edge of any closed curved line.', 'Annulus - A ring-shaped region bounded by two concentric circles.', 'Periphery - The outer limit or boundary of an area, often used in a figurative sense to denote marginality.', 'Circular motion - Motion along the circumference of a circle at constant speed.', 'Circle graph/pie chart - A circular statistical graphic that displays numerical proportions as sectors of a circle.', 'Circumlocution - The use of many words to express an idea, often in a roundabout or evasive manner.', 'Orbit - The curved path one object takes around another due to gravity.', 'Rondel - A small circular ring worn as jewelry, especially during the Middle Ages.', 'Circumvent - To find a way (typically a difficult or complex) around an obstacle; bypass.', 'Circle dance - A form of group folk dancing in which dancers hold hands and move in circles.', "Annular eclipse - An astronomical event where the moon's shadow during a lunar eclipse creates a ring-like appearance (annulus) around the eclipsed sun.", 'Circumnavigation - The action of going completely around something, especially by traveling through all points on its boundary; to circumnavigate.', 'Ring - A circular band worn as jewelry or used in various structures and objects.', 'Annual (or annual ring) - A visible layer formed each year within the growth rings of trees, indicating age.', 'Circuitous route - An indirect way that is longer than a more direct path to reach a destination.', 'Loophole - A specific provision or situation that allows for an escape from what is legally required or permissible by circumventing the intended effect of a rule, law, or argument.', 'Circumstance - The conditions and facts pertaining to a particular event or situation at a given time.']

['Jeans - A type of durable trousers often made from denim, popular for their casual and versatile style.', "Slacks - Men's dress pants with straight cuts; can also be used to describe women's tailored pants.", 'Chinos - Casual trousers made of cotton twill, typically in khaki or neutral colors.', 'Pantaloons - Full-length trousers that extend below the knee.', 'Capri pants - Skinny, cropped trousers that end between the ankle and the calf.', 'Leggings - Close-fitting stretchy trousers worn under skirts or dresses for warmth or support.', 'Joggers - Casual trousers with a drawstring waist, often featuring elastic cuffs to keep out drafts and dirt.', "Capri panties - Skin-tight women's underwear that ends around the calf area or slightly higher.", 'Pantsuit - A matching set of jacket and trousers, typically worn by women for a formal occasion.', 'Tights - Thin nylon pants covering legs and feet, often worn beneath skirts or dresses.', 'Hosiery - Close-fitting knitted garments that cover the lower part of the leg from knee to foot.', 'Pantaloons - An old term for long trousers that extend below the ankle, sometimes associated with Victorian fashion.', 'Jeggings - A hybrid between leggings and denim pants; ['Amputee - A person who has had one or more limbs removed due to injury, disease, or medical necessity.', 'Ex-soldier - Someone who may have lost limbs while serving in military conflicts.', 'Paraplegic/Paralyzed - Refers to someone with partial or total loss of lower body functioning, which can sometimes lead to the amputation of affected limbs.', 'Double-amputee - A person who has had both legs removed.', 'Bilateral Amputee - Similar to double-amputee but usually refers specifically to a bilateral leg amputation.', 'Prosthesis wearer - Someone using artificial limbs in place of severed ones, though not a synonym for having lost limbs themselves.', 'Limb loss survivor - A person who has lived through and adapted after the loss of one or more limbs.', 'Lifelong amputee - An individual who has had an amputation since birth due to various conditions.', 'War veteran with amputations - Veterans of wars where severe injuries, including limb amputations, were commonplace.', 'Disability advocate - Someone fighting for the rights and betterment of individuals who have lost limbs or other physical abilities.', "Limb-sparing surgeon - A medical professional specializing in complex reconstructive surgery to save a patient's remaining limb.", 'Amputee advocate - An individual actively working to improve the lives and treatment of those with amputations.', 'Handicapped person - Generally used as an outdated term, but it can refer to someone who has lost limbs or other physical disabilities.', 'Invalid/Invalided - Describing a state after having suffered severe injuries resulting in the loss of limbs; not synonymous with amputation itself.', 'Traumatic injury patient - Someone who has experienced significant harm, potentially leading to limb loss due to accidents or violence.', 'Multiple amputee - A person who has had two or more limbs removed.', 'Veteran with prosthetics - Military veterans using artificial limbs after losing them during service.', 'Amputation recipient - One who receives the surgical procedure of amputation, not necessarily someone still living with their disability.', 'Missing person case - A situation where a loved one is reported missing and presumed to have lost limbs or otherwise been harmed, though unrelated directly to them having an actual amputation.', 'Limb loss charity worker - An individual working for organizations dedicated to helping those who have experienced the loss of their limbs.']
